column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=DS : What would you say the atmosphere was like on campus back then , with all the issues that were being contended with , how would you describe it ?

#Text=NS : I do n’t think it was that different than the atmosphere on law school campuses now , David , which is to say that even at the height — and statistics I have read have verified this — even at the height of the student activist movement , it was still a fairly small percentage of students who were really engaged , especially in law school .
#Text=In college there were more involved in the anti-war movement , but in law school most people were just trying to get good grades and good jobs .
#Text=I do n’t say that at all disparagingly .
#Text=There was a core of people who gravitated toward these extracurricular activities and back in those days you got no course credit at all .
#Text=Now most law schools give course credit , so you would have to do all of that on ‘ ’ top ’ ’ of your full time course load .
#Text=And if you can believe it , the Harvard Law Review , which I was also on , you got no course credit for that .

#Text=What I ’m saying is that I was n’t really linked to the law school , per se ; my experience was — and I cut a lot of classes , quite frankly — my experience was going to the legal aid bureau , going to the voluntary defenders office , meeting with my clients , doing that kind of work .
#Text=Law school classes and exams was just something I had to get through to get my degree .
#Text=But I did n’t feel myself so connected to Harvard Law School as an entity .
#Text=Religion in schools
#Text=DS : You had mentioned that one of the things that affected you with your family was seeing points of view not being allowed to be expressed .
#Text=Many religious conservatives would say that the ACLU opposes having their points of view in the schools .
#Text=How would you respond ?
#Text=NS :

#Text=That is absolutely untrue , but I know that myth and distortion of what we have advocated and what the Supreme Court has held , there are so many myths and misrepresentations about that , and the truth is that every individual , whether student or teacher , should be completely free in a nondiscriminatory process , to express whatever ideas or beliefs he or she has as long as it is consistent with the overall educational mission .

#Text=So just as it would be inappropriate for a student to stand up in the middle of math class and say , “ Join the ACLU ! ” it would be inappropriate for a student to stand up in the middle of math class and say , “ Join the Hare Krishna or the Christian Coalition ! ”

#Text=But in forums where it is appropriate for individuals to discuss ideas openly , such as extracurricular periods , lunch periods , maybe there are times before or after the school day , then every viewpoint should be welcome equally , whether it be pro-religion , anti-religion , any religion , any politics , you name it .
